annotations.text: I dedicate my body and mind, my whole life, to the practice of the Lord Buddha’s teachings in their entirety. I will realize the truth in this lifetime … I will let go of everything and follow the teachings. No matter how much suffering and difficulty I have to endure I will persevere, otherwise there will be no end to my doubts. I will make this life as even and continuous as a single day and night. I will abandon attachments to mind and body and follow the Buddha’s teachings until I know their truth for myself.|Ajahn Chah
annotations.body: Quote: “I dedicate my body and mind, my whole life, to the practice of the Lord Buddha’s teachings in their entirety. I will realize the truth in this lifetime … I will let go of everything and follow the teachings. No matter how much suffering and difficulty I have to endure I will persevere, otherwise there will be no end to my doubts. I will make this life as even and continuous as a single day and night. I will abandon attachments to mind and body and follow the Buddha’s teachings until I know their truth for myself.” — Ajahn Chah

annotations.text: I dedicate my body and mind, my whole life, to the practice of the Lord Buddha’s teachings in their entirety. I will realize the truth in this lifetime … I will let go of everything and follow the teachings. No matter how much suffering and difficulty I have to endure I will persevere, otherwise there will be no end to my doubts. I will make this life as even and continuous as a single day and night. I will abandon attachments to mind and body and follow the Buddha’s teachings until I know their truth for myself.|Ajahn Chah
annotations.body: Quote: “I dedicate my body and mind, my whole life, to the practice of the Lord Buddha’s teachings in their entirety. I will realize the truth in this lifetime … I will let go of everything and follow the teachings. No matter how much suffering and difficulty I have to endure I will persevere, otherwise there will be no end to my doubts. I will make this life as even and continuous as a single day and night. I will abandon attachments to mind and body and follow the Buddha’s teachings until I know their truth for myself.” — Ajahn Chah

excerpts.text: You spoke about suffusing the body with extreme well-being. But I've been in states like that and my body seems to disappear.

annotations.body: Response by Ajahn Pasanno.

annotations.text: It isn't so much the experience of extreme well-being that is the goal. It's the ability to gain clarity and stability so that one can see through the experience as something that is uncertain or impermanent, has a changing nature. The mind often wants to disregard that. The tendency to identify self with experience on a refined mental level is tempered by the body experience.
annotations.body: Quote: “It isn’t so much the experience of extreme well-being that is the goal. It’s the ability to gain clarity and stability so that one can see through the experience as something that is uncertain or impermanent, has a changing nature. The mind often wants to disregard that. The tendency to identify self with experience on a refined mental level is tempered by the body experience.”

annotations.text: Are you saying you can become attached to these states?

annotations.text: I don't care. Not in the sense that I don't think it's serious or that it's not a problem. But I don't care in the sense that I don't want to be getting involved in whatever side people are working themselves up about, because the problem is much deeper than that. We have to pay attention to the deeper problem, both in the human condition and politically.

excerpts.text: When she is talking about the mind at normalcy, her description is having the meditation object always at least in the background, constantly in awareness, being aware of the mind-state and also doing whatever you are doing, walking, washing dishes etc. Her emphasis is on cultivating it so this is something that you would be doing twenty-four hours a day. When Ajahn Chah spoke of normalcy of the mind, did he describe it in the same way?
excerpts.body: “When she is talking about the mind at normalcy, her description is having the meditation object always at least in the background, constantly in awareness, being aware of the mind-state and also doing whatever you are doing, walking, washing dishes etc. Her emphasis is on cultivating it so this is something that you would be doing twenty-four hours a day. When Ajahn Chah spoke of normalcy of the mind, did he describe it in the same way?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: She talks about within this state of normalcy constantly contemplating the three characteristics of all phenomena occurring in awareness. To me that sounds like juggling a bunch of things!

annotations.body: Response by Ajahn Pasanno.

excerpts.body: Comment: She talks about within this state of normalcy constantly contemplating the three characteristics of all phenomena occurring in awareness. To me that sounds like juggling a bunch of things!

excerpts.text: So the ability to hold the meditation object, go through your daily routines, keep an eye on the mind tone, and watch the stress flavor of all arising phenomenon seems like a fairly advanced practice state to arrive at and maintain twenty-four hours a day.

excerpts.text: You were talking about the positive aspect of relinquishment, and that's what will motivate giving up, that positive aspect of giving up and letting go. When it's painful giving up and you give up, you can say, 'Wait, I'm just focusing on the negative aspect of giving up, I need to switch my mind to the benefits of relinquishment?'
excerpts.body: “You were talking about the positive aspect of relinquishment, and that’s what will motivate giving up, that positive aspect of giving up and letting go. When it’s painful giving up and you give up, you can say, ‘Wait, I’m just focusing on the negative aspect of giving up, I need to switch my mind to the benefits of relinquishment?’” {attribution}

excerpts.text: The purpose and function [of practice] always come back to the alleviation of suffering and the relinquishment of self-view....The take-away bit of the forest teachers or ethos is that we have everything within us....They are coming at it from all different angles, but the underlying thread is that theme of relying on and refining capabilities that we actually have. Sīla, samādhi, and pañña are not external to us.

Sīla, samādhi, and pañña are not external to us.” {attribution}

annotations.text: There is that which is beyond birth and death. And then you start asking, 'Well, what is it and how is it? How should it be?' It's just the same as in the Sabbāsava Sutta (MN 2.7)...As soon as you get into conceiving, you've already started the process of dukkha.
annotations.body: Quote: “There is that which is beyond birth and death. And then you start asking, ‘Well, what is it and how is it? How should it be?’ It’s just the same as in the Sabbāsava Sutta (MN 2.7)...As soon as you get into conceiving, you’ve already started the process of dukkha.”

Much gratitude.

excerpts.text: How do I use the teaching today about investigating the cause of suffering when working with betrayal? Been married to high school sweetheart for 40 years. Raised children together and best of friends. Lately he has gone off the deep end. Midlife crisis? - who knows, but he started drinking and acting out sexually. The feelings of shock, betrayal, hurt, anger and fear are beyond words. If new relationship I would leave, but he has been in my life since I was a child. Impossible to accept but hard to leave. How do I find the cause of suffering (noble truth) you spoke of today? And how to bring some equanimity and space around this?

excerpts.body: “There is a borderline between being fierceful (in a wholesome way) and being aggressive.  I can’t say anything about Dhamma teachers as I have never experienced Thai Ajahns, but a few yoga teachers I’ve studied with in my opinion were rather just exercising their power over students. How to tell the difference between a teacher who genuinely means well to their students while acting fierce-fully from someone on a power trip?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: I've wondered for some time how to put together (a) birth, aging, and death are dukkha and (b) the cause of dukkha as craving. Is it correct to say that the source of dukkha is in the mind (i.e., craving)? If so, what does it mean to say that birth, aging, and death—facts that we don't control and can't change—are dukkha? Thank you for your generosity and wisdom.

Thank you for your generosity and wisdom.” {attribution}

excerpts.text: A question regarding the 5 precepts. In daily life, I am really good about keeping #1, 2, 3 and 5; but somehow I found that the precept #4 is really hard. I find myself lying everyday such as: 'Do I look good?' → Yes, of course. 'Do you want to eat some more?' → No, thanks, I’m full (but in fact the food didn’t taste good). Or speaking at a wrong time, speaking too long, toos hort, too harsh or speaking with a wrong tone of voice. This is the hardest one for me. Kindly advise. Thank you.

annotations.text: The function of the precepts in terms of practice is to provide a mirror so we can understand our own intentions and volitions.

excerpts.text: I’ve recently been blessed with two local Dhamma teachers separately teaching on the hindrances. Both suggested noticing when the hindrances are not present. That’s been a hard concept to recognize. Today’s teachings on looking at the opposite of a hindrance when it is present allowed me to become consciously aware and look at 'why is the opposite not present in this moment' and 'what I need to release the hindrance?' I guess I’m a right-brain person. Thank you for the change in perspective.

So in a way I have been doing all my recent walking meditations with a little sadness over not having yet overcome sexual desire, and not being to enter jhāna as easily and happily as Ajahn Karuṇadhammo describes. What do I do?

excerpts.text: If the body is a sack of grains, my legs after 7 / 7:30pm are electric jumping beans. This has occurred on retreat for 30 years. At first, I assumed it was the usual resistances / saṅkhāras. For a decade, I’ve known it’s a neurological syndrome that many have (R.L.S.) and although it affects other parts of life, e.g., sleep, it’s never so intense as on retreat in the evening. As I calm and cleanse, it actually gets worse, even on longer retreats. If I don’t focus on exhaling calm and mettā, I would drive my neighbors crazy, twitching and squirming like a bored 4 year-old. But I’m not bored and I want to hear the teachings. The level of controlling the legs necessarily, even with calming, creates sometimes a kind of negative pīti—thunderbolts in the body with no delight or rapture! I intuit an ancient root to it but, what to do? Alternative and western guidance have not helped much. From your vast experience of squirming mediators, any advice? Any research on sitting and milder neurological phenomena like this? Right now, besides leaving the hall / tortured endurance / drugs / cutting off my legs, suggestions for a middle way?!
excerpts.body: “If the body is a sack of grains, my legs after 7 / 7:30pm are electric jumping beans. This has occurred on retreat for 30 years. At first, I assumed it was the usual resistances / saṅkhāras. For a decade, I’ve known it’s a neurological syndrome that many have (R.L.S.) and although it affects other parts of life, e.g., sleep, it’s never so intense as on retreat in the evening. As I calm and cleanse, it actually gets worse, even on longer retreats. If I don’t focus on exhaling calm and mettā, I would drive my neighbors crazy, twitching and squirming like a bored 4 year-old. But I’m not bored and I want to hear the teachings. The level of controlling the legs necessarily, even with calming, creates sometimes a kind of negative pīti—thunderbolts in the body with no delight or rapture! I intuit an ancient root to it but, what to do? Alternative and western guidance have not helped much. From your vast experience of squirming mediators, any advice? Any research on sitting and milder neurological phenomena like this? Right now, besides leaving the hall / tortured endurance / drugs / cutting off my legs, suggestions for a middle way?!” {attribution}

excerpts.text: I would like to invite my aging mother to live with my family. Our family observes the precept of no-killing. However, my mother is not vegetarian. My spouse insists that everyone in the house must uphold the precept. I think it’s unfair to impose that on my aging mother. Is my spouse holding onto fixed views? I very much would like to honor my filial duty and at the same time maintain harmony in the family. As a practitioner, what is the best way to handle this situation? Thank you, Ajahn, for your time and advice.

excerpts.text: I love clues that help identify that some experience is or is not what I thought it is. For example, Ajahn Ñāniko’s point that just a blank purely absorbed state is not jhāna, (a wrong conclusion anybody any get to) and that instead it should be more 'broad-based' and mettā-bhāvanā is very useful for that. This sort of 'TEST' for the labels we may jump to apply to our experience is very useful insight—'cool' if I may say. Are there more such 'tests?' P.S. This is to help prevent my mind from becoming too proud, or thinking I have attained some state when not.
excerpts.body: “I love clues that help identify that some experience is or is not what I thought it is. For example, Ajahn Ñāniko’s point that just a blank purely absorbed state is not jhāna, (a wrong conclusion anybody any get to) and that instead it should be more ‘broad-based’ and mettā-bhāvanā is very useful for that. This sort of ‘TEST’ for the labels we may jump to apply to our experience is very useful insight—‘cool’ if I may say. Are there more such ‘tests?’ P.S. This is to help prevent my mind from becoming too proud, or thinking I have attained some state when not.” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Thank you for talking about the nun who got enlightened the other day. Also thanks to Debbie for her talk! As a female myself, I find it inspirational hearing stories about women on the path. Most teachers, well-known disciples, the Buddha himself, were males, so at times I struggled to connect to the teachings. It felt too mind-focused, too 'male' (as more women in my view connect through the heart, or at least I do). I see a lot of heart and compassion in the Dhamma now and I am learning more about women in Buddhism. It would be great to hear more stories about them in Dhamma talks and perhaps one day even have a guest nun visit and give a talk. Thank you.
excerpts.body: “Thank you for talking about the nun who got enlightened the other day. Also thanks to Debbie for her talk! As a female myself, I find it inspirational hearing stories about women on the path. Most teachers, well-known disciples, the Buddha himself, were males, so at times I struggled to connect to the teachings. It felt too mind-focused, too ‘male’ (as more women in my view connect through the heart, or at least I do). I see a lot of heart and compassion in the Dhamma now and I am learning more about women in Buddhism. It would be great to hear more stories about them in Dhamma talks and perhaps one day even have a guest nun visit and give a talk. Thank you.” {attribution}

How does one balance the two?

excerpts.text: Thank you Ajahn Ñāniko for encouraging us to see Dhamma in hearts around us, and within. Apart from your beloved teachers and tradition, where else in our modern world do you see Dhamma in the hearts of those who also in various ways seek the end of suffering for all? Who particularly inspires you? Who is worthy of respect? For example, your support of Julia Butterfly Hill was inspired by her courage and heart, correct? Also, could a future Buddha be in the Sangha? Is it already happening? Your thoughts, Ajahn Pasanno and those of your esteemed company appreciated.

excerpts.text: Thank you so much for these wonderful teachings. Sometimes a very intense light nimitta arises and it feels like all of my energy rushes to my forehead. I try to ignore the nimitta but it gets brighter and undulating. I try to pull it down to my feet but that doesn’t work. I’ve tried all sorts of things but ultimately I just stop sitting; start walking. The nimitta gives me a headache and is draining. 1) Why does it happen? 2) What to do? Deep gratitude.
excerpts.body: “Thank you so much for these wonderful teachings. Sometimes a very intense light nimitta arises and it feels like all of my energy rushes to my forehead. I try to ignore the nimitta but it gets brighter and undulating. I try to pull it down to my feet but that doesn’t work. I’ve tried all sorts of things but ultimately I just stop sitting; start walking. The nimitta gives me a headache and is draining. 1) Why does it happen? 2) What to do? Deep gratitude.” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Following this morning’s talk on non-self, do you have any advice for reflecting on remorse / regret in the context of non-self? Remorse / regret are usually not big in my life except in one area: that of missed obligations to others. Investigation in this area rarely fortifies or informs me. It usually triggers either a well-tuned system of aversion / distraction or else despair. I do have confidence in the Buddha’s teachings and so an inkling that this can all be dismantled somehow. It’s quite a small inkle but it did try to get my attention this morning so any reflections or directions are deeply appreciated.

excerpts.text: I enjoy the teaching about devas, they seem to be a good counter-balance for left-brain people. Is it correct to say that the Hindu deities are included into the Buddhist universe as higher devas, mighty but not omniscient and impermanent beings? I am particularly interested in Shiva, who for me is a positive symbol of cessation, relinquishment and play of the elements. I know that Brahma is mentioned a lot in the Canon, but what about Shiva? Also, since Thailand borrowed a lot from Indian culture, are there any devotional practices for Hindu deities, and if yes are they somehow integrated with Buddhism, perhaps on a folk level?

Also, since Thailand borrowed a lot from Indian culture, are there any devotional practices for Hindu deities, and if yes are they somehow integrated with Buddhism, perhaps on a folk level?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: I was practicing yogic prāṇāyāma for about a year to alleviate a medical problem. However, as my practice develops I notice effects on the mind particularly during breath retentions. Yogic literature states that there is a complete and spontaneous cessation of breath in full samādhi. Is it true that some scriptural Buddhist sources say that there is a cessation of breath in the fourth jhāna too?
excerpts.body: “I was practicing yogic prāṇāyāma for about a year to alleviate a medical problem. However, as my practice develops I notice effects on the mind particularly during breath retentions. Yogic literature states that there is a complete and spontaneous cessation of breath in full samādhi. Is it true that some scriptural Buddhist sources say that there is a cessation of breath in the fourth jhāna too?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Overall, why do you think there is no application of conscious control of breath in Buddhist practice, e.g., no scriptural references to prolonged exhalations to help calm down the mind? Is it conceivable to speculate that Gautama Buddha did practice prāṇāyāmas with his two teachers before joining the ascetics but somehow did not find them useful?

Is it conceivable to speculate that Gautama Buddha did practice prāṇāyāmas with his two teachers before joining the ascetics but somehow did not find them useful?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: After the Abhayagiri community begins the retreat with the ceremony of taking dependence, Ajahn Pasanno explains the meaning of dependence, the importance of mindfulness, and how mindfulness connects with the eightfold path. excerpts.text: Ajahn Pasanno reflects upon the question: “What kind of effort do we need to conform with what the Buddha means by mindfulness?” He answers in terms of the four aspects of right effort, the seven qualities of Dhamma the Buddha taught to Upali (AN 7.79), and the Buddha's description of how he crossed the flood (SN 1.1).

excerpts.text: One of the things I often attend to is the juxtaposition of stillness and movement. It's not that one is right and the other wrong. We can be still and really dull or the mind can move with clarity and acuity. But stillness and movement, what's generating it, what's pushing it? That bhavadiṭṭhi/vibhavadiṭṭhi is the engine behind it and the force behing the arising of a sense of self, a sense of me.
excerpts.body: Quote: “One of the things I often attend to is the juxtaposition of stillness and movement. It’s not that one is right and the other wrong. We can be still and really dull or the mind can move with clarity and acuity. But stillness and movement, what’s generating it, what’s pushing it? That bhavadiṭṭhi/vibhavadiṭṭhi is the engine behind it and the force behing the arising of a sense of self, a sense of me.” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Could you speak on working with sanna in meditation?  Over these days there is an experience of heightened sensitivity to perception and the initial contact that gives rise to thought and feeling.  In particular, I notice how an inaccurate perception, seen as inaccurate, gives rise to thought formations that move forward as if based on an accurate perception.  This moves fast in the mind feels somewhat trippy and disorienting.  How does one develop the skill of sensitivity and perception so as to have durability in daily life?

excerpts.text: I have a moral dilemma to ask you about.  Someone I know, let’s call him Henry (who is also a Buddhist) recently went to the pet store and saw this “bearded dragon” lizard which he felt sorry for and so he bought it and brought it home.  Normally, this would be a good thing since it was Henry’s intention to simply take care of the lizard and give it a good home, since the lizard looked sad and miserable at the pet store.  Unfortunately, the lizard diet requires that he be fed live baby crickets for hi protein needs. Apparently lizards can’t eat dead things and need some protein for their normal growth.  I told Henry that this is really bad, especially for Henry’s karma and the poor crickets.  So I told Henry to set the lizard into the wild and let it survive on its own.  Henry says that according to his research, 90% of lizards bred in captivity die in the wild.   So Henry cannot, in good conscience, set the lizard into the wild, basically giving him a death sentence.  Henry does not want this since he cares for the lizard.  I then told Henry to give the lizard away to another family.  Henry says that this will also cause someone else to have bad karma since the lizard’s dietary needs will be the same.  There seems to be no good solution.  Would you please comment?
excerpts.body: “I have a moral dilemma to ask you about.  Someone I know, let’s call him Henry (who is also a Buddhist) recently went to the pet store and saw this “bearded dragon” lizard which he felt sorry for and so he bought it and brought it home.  Normally, this would be a good thing since it was Henry’s intention to simply take care of the lizard and give it a good home, since the lizard looked sad and miserable at the pet store.  Unfortunately, the lizard diet requires that he be fed live baby crickets for hi protein needs. Apparently lizards can’t eat dead things and need some protein for their normal growth.  I told Henry that this is really bad, especially for Henry’s karma and the poor crickets.  So I told Henry to set the lizard into the wild and let it survive on its own.  Henry says that according to his research, 90% of lizards bred in captivity die in the wild.   So Henry cannot, in good conscience, set the lizard into the wild, basically giving him a death sentence.  Henry does not want this since he cares for the lizard.  I then told Henry to give the lizard away to another family.  Henry says that this will also cause someone else to have bad karma since the lizard’s dietary needs will be the same.  There seems to be no good solution.  Would you please comment?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: My dearest parents -in-law - very ill, 82-84 years old, live in Europe.  My dear husband loves his mother very much.  He said if his mother passes away, he doesn’t want to be in the funeral.  I don’t think it is a good idea. How can I help him and myself in the way of Buddha mind?  I am afraid my husband will break down.
excerpts.body: “My dearest parents -in-law - very ill, 82-84 years old, live in Europe.  My dear husband loves his mother very much.  He said if his mother passes away, he doesn’t want to be in the funeral.  I don’t think it is a good idea. How can I help him and myself in the way of Buddha mind?  I am afraid my husband will break down.” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Please repeat the phrase that included “nimitta” and your name in some form.  Can you give context/expand a little on this?

excerpts.text: What is the difference between loving kindness and compassion?  How can one evoke/manifest them if he/she never experienced them before?

excerpts.text: It seems I have returned to remedial meditation practice.  I can’t seem to find ease in my body, let alone my breath.  It feels like I’m stuck in physical pain - an invisible barrier I can’t seem to penetrate.  Acceptance and loving kindness are being applied, but without much movement.  I am trying to develop concentration on breath - so far no piti or sukha.  What to do?

It feels like I’m stuck in physical pain - an invisible barrier I can’t seem to penetrate.  Acceptance and loving kindness are being applied, but without much movement.  I am trying to develop concentration on breath - so far no piti or sukha.  What to do?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: I was struck by the suggestion you shared about orienting oneself toward what one can give to a moment rather than what one can get from a moment.  This mind shift seems hugely beneficial.  Would you expand on this?
excerpts.body: “I was struck by the suggestion you shared about orienting oneself toward what one can give to a moment rather than what one can get from a moment.  This mind shift seems hugely beneficial.  Would you expand on this?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Is there a difference between mindfulness and awareness?
excerpts.body: “Is there a difference between mindfulness and awareness?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: As I get deeper insights how conditioned the mind is, there is a sense of burden being released but also a doubt began to arise:  If the mind is conditioned, how is it even possible to arrive at the Unconditioned?  Does free will even exist or am I just pushed around by kilesas?  If the trick is to recognize that there is no free will, how can I sincerely believe that when I’m making choices to practice and do wholesome deeds, they really matter and it’s not my delusion? Please dispel my doubts!
excerpts.body: “As I get deeper insights how conditioned the mind is, there is a sense of burden being released but also a doubt began to arise:  If the mind is conditioned, how is it even possible to arrive at the Unconditioned?  Does free will even exist or am I just pushed around by kilesas?  If the trick is to recognize that there is no free will, how can I sincerely believe that when I’m making choices to practice and do wholesome deeds, they really matter and it’s not my delusion? Please dispel my doubts!” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Could you describe the detail of the four noble truths?  What are they?  How do we apply  them to real modern lives?

excerpts.text: Please explain the seven factors of awakening and how to practice them in this retreat.

excerpts.text: Would you please talk a little bit about determination versus compassion in meditation?  For example, as long sittings can cause pain and legs to go numb, when is it good to use determination to power through?  And when is it good to have compassion for the body and also not cause damage to the body, so that it can be healthy for long-term practice?

For example, as long sittings can cause pain and legs to go numb, when is it good to use determination to power through?  And when is it good to have compassion for the body and also not cause damage to the body, so that it can be healthy for long-term practice?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: If someone spreads a harmful story about another that is untrue, but has convinced her/himself it is true (including her/his own embellishments), does this break the fourth precept?
excerpts.body: “If someone spreads a harmful story about another that is untrue, but has convinced her/himself it is true (including her/his own embellishments), does this break the fourth precept?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: It’s a common phrase:  “If you see the Buddha on the road, kill him.”  Obviously it’s using hyperbole for effect but I think it means to trust only in your own experience.  At what point do the guidelines and precepts leave off and the way to proceed on findings begins? I know it’s not a linear path, but I’d appreciate your thoughts.
excerpts.body: “It’s a common phrase:  “If you see the Buddha on the road, kill him.”  Obviously it’s using hyperbole for effect but I think it means to trust only in your own experience.  At what point do the guidelines and precepts leave off and the way to proceed on findings begins? I know it’s not a linear path, but I’d appreciate your thoughts.” {attribution}

excerpts.text: The Asavas:  Why does the mind leave (“go out”) its still center?
excerpts.body: “The Asavas:  Why does the mind leave (“go out”) its still center?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Is it true that it’s bad or disrespectful to point one’s heel at a monk?  I thought that I read or heard this somewhere.  Sometimes I have felt the necessity to stretch out one leg or the other in the meditation hall, but as all the monastics sit up front, I feel that I will be pointing my heel at one monastic or another and I really don’t want to be disrespectful if this is so.  Or is this worrying too much about conventions which causes suffering?
excerpts.body: “Is it true that it’s bad or disrespectful to point one’s heel at a monk?  I thought that I read or heard this somewhere.  Sometimes I have felt the necessity to stretch out one leg or the other in the meditation hall, but as all the monastics sit up front, I feel that I will be pointing my heel at one monastic or another and I really don’t want to be disrespectful if this is so.  Or is this worrying too much about conventions which causes suffering?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: When I sit for longer periods, I experience involuntary jerking and shaking.  I can suppress it, but in doubt if this is a good idea.
excerpts.body: “When I sit for longer periods, I experience involuntary jerking and shaking.  I can suppress it, but in doubt if this is a good idea.” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Can you please talk about some of the changes in the new version of the morning chant and which ones, if any, (and why) resonate with you?
excerpts.body: “Can you please talk about some of the changes in the new version of the morning chant and which ones, if any, (and why) resonate with you?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: As I consider which aspects of my life could be simplified, it occurs to me that I have two different friendships which may no longer be worth the trade off in time or energy.  After spending time with either of these friends, I tend to be more drained of my very limited energy, possible because neither is very self-aware and both talk a lot.  What is my obligation to an old friend who has recently come through a really hard time in her life or to a new friend whose health and living situation are precarious.  Is there a graceful way to bow out of a friendship without harming the other person?
excerpts.body: “As I consider which aspects of my life could be simplified, it occurs to me that I have two different friendships which may no longer be worth the trade off in time or energy.  After spending time with either of these friends, I tend to be more drained of my very limited energy, possible because neither is very self-aware and both talk a lot.  What is my obligation to an old friend who has recently come through a really hard time in her life or to a new friend whose health and living situation are precarious.  Is there a graceful way to bow out of a friendship without harming the other person?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: I am away from a social network for almost six days which is quite incredible for me.  Normally, I spend time by distracting with the social network every 10 minutes.  I must check and see what people are doing, and sometimes I think is it is quite useless.  This is a different world.  However, I cannot stop using it. I am so attached to it, and I know I will go back to the same routine when I go back to my normal life.  What would you suggest to detach or use it wisely?
excerpts.body: “I am away from a social network for almost six days which is quite incredible for me.  Normally, I spend time by distracting with the social network every 10 minutes.  I must check and see what people are doing, and sometimes I think is it is quite useless.  This is a different world.  However, I cannot stop using it. I am so attached to it, and I know I will go back to the same routine when I go back to my normal life.  What would you suggest to detach or use it wisely?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: When one dies, do they carry memory of their former life into their next life?  Is it possible to make amends from the former life into the next life?

excerpts.body: “This morning you talked about sense, object, contact, feeling, etc. and gave the example of the eye and object coming in contact.  The sixth sense is the heart/mind, correct?  And the object is the heart/mind?  Can you give an example?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: Does having no craving mean doing things in the world knowing they won’t bring lasting satisfaction?  For example, planning a vacation realizing that it will eventually end or taking measures to cure a headache without expecting to feel completely better.  I am trying to understand how this would look like in real life without one becoming apathetic and depressed about the meaninglessness of basically all activities except meditation.  How to balance  the ability to still enjoy life with abandoning all craving?

excerpts.text: Please demystify jhana a little for those like myself whose vipassana past has had minimal samadhi focus.  The emphasis on calming and brightening has been so helpful.  Whereas in past I associated deep concentration with vipassana elites and insight practice more for those living in the mess of the world, now I wonder, in our post election universe,  whether a more jhanic or balance between practices would prevent overwhelm, hiding, running to Canada! Thoughts?

Thoughts?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: “There is a crack in everything.  That’s where the light gets in”  Leonard Cohen  Lots of cracks out there.  Lots of potential for awakenings and wise compassionate action.  Do you agree?  If so, where do you see the light emerging?  In what arenas?  Where would you focus your energy if you were not a monk?

Do you bless everyone with a chant who gives you food?

excerpts.text: Yesterday when you spoke of women’s ordination in California, I thought of the nuns at Aloka Vihara Forest Monastery who left the Thai Forest Tradition to ordain as nuns.  As a woman who has felt a strong calling to the monastic life, I feel a painful split in my heart between the love I have for the Thai Forest Tradition that has changed my life,  and its seemingly uncompassionate regard for women wishing to live the Holy Life. It leaves me with a profound feeling of hurt and “less-than” mana.  I have to believe that the Buddha, who revolutionarily taught against the caste system, would not want me to feel like second class member of the human race when trying to live a life in his example.  I have tried bringing self compassion to this felt sense of my heart breaking, but the pain seems to get worse with the association of the teachers of the Thai Forest tradition who showed me the dharma and yet follow this “anti-nun" rule.  Would you share some words of healing to help my heart and restore my faith in this tradition that has so profoundly changed my life?
excerpts.body: “Yesterday when you spoke of women’s ordination in California, I thought of the nuns at Aloka Vihara Forest Monastery who left the Thai Forest Tradition to ordain as nuns.  As a woman who has felt a strong calling to the monastic life, I feel a painful split in my heart between the love I have for the Thai Forest Tradition that has changed my life,  and its seemingly uncompassionate regard for women wishing to live the Holy Life. It leaves me with a profound feeling of hurt and “less-than” mana.  I have to believe that the Buddha, who revolutionarily taught against the caste system, would not want me to feel like second class member of the human race when trying to live a life in his example.  I have tried bringing self compassion to this felt sense of my heart breaking, but the pain seems to get worse with the association of the teachers of the Thai Forest tradition who showed me the dharma and yet follow this “anti-nun” rule.  Would you share some words of healing to help my heart and restore my faith in this tradition that has so profoundly changed my life?” {attribution}

excerpts.text: A question about Dogenji's teaching: 'To study the Buddha Way is to study the self. To study the self is to forget the self. To forget the self is to be actualized by myriad things. When actualized by myriad things your body and mind as well as the bodies and minds of others drop away. No trace of enlightenment remains, and this no trace continues endlessly.' Can you reflect on this teaching from the Theravāda Thai Forest Teachings?

No trace of enlightenment remains, and this no trace continues endlessly.’ Can you reflect on this teaching from the Theravāda Thai Forest Teachings?” {attribution}

Chah2001.title: Remembering Ajahn Chah Weekend
Chah2001.description: On April 28-29, 2001, over 200 people gathered in Portola Valley to honor the life and teachings of Ajahn Chah. Senior monastic disciples, former monks and nuns, and people who briefly encountered Ajahn Chah recollect their experiences of this great teacher.

SRD2010.title: Recollections of Ajahn Chah
SRD2010.subtitle: His Life and Teachings
SRD2010.description: During this daylong retreat, Ajahn Pasanno shares teachings and memories of his beloved teacher, Ajahn Chah. By the time of his passing in 1992, Ajahn Chah had become one of the most highly revered Buddhist meditation masters in Thailand. The readings come from a draft version of Ajahn Jayasaro’s biography of Ajahn Chah that was published as Stillness Flowing in 2018.

SRD2011.title: Tudong Stories at Spirit Rock
SRD2011.description: Ajahn Pasanno offers stories of tudong (wandering pilgrimage) at a daylong event at Spirit Rock Meditation Center

UD2012-4.title: The Gradual Training
UD2012-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno and Ajahn Yatiko describe the Buddha’s progressive teaching, which begins by encouraging generosity and virtue and goes on to describe the joys of heaven, the drawbacks in sensuality, the benefits of renunciation, and the Four Noble Truths.

UD2013-1.title: Right Livelihood
UD2013-1.description: Ajahn Pasanno reads from P. A. Payutto’s Buddhist Economics and A Constitution for Living and answers questions related to the topic of Right Livelihood.

TG2013.title: Abhayagiri Monastic Retreat 2013
TG2013.subtitle: Brightening the Mind
TG2013.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

WR2014.title: Abhayagiri 2014 Winter Retreat
WR2014.subtitle: Our Roots in the Thai Forest Tradition
WR2014.description: The Abhayagiri Community take turns reading from translations of the Thai Forest masters. Ajahn Pasanno answers many questions following the readings.

UD2014-1.title: Death and Dying
UD2014-1.description: Sutta readings, reflections, personal stories, and questions about dying, death, and grief.

UD2014-2.title: Thai Forest Tradition
UD2014-2.description: Stories and readings about the origins and characteristics of the Thai Forest tradion.

UD2014-3.title: Mindfulness of Breathing
UD2014-3.description: Ajahn Pasanno describes mindfulness of breathing as a method to firmly establish the mind and develop insight.

DRBU2014.title: Questions and Answers with Dharma Realm Buddhist University
DRBU2014.description: A small group from the Dharma Realm Buddhist University (DRBU) located at the City of Ten Thousand Buddhas (CTTB) spent the morning at Abhayagiri. The group included two bhikkshunis as well as a number of resident volunteers at the CTTB. The students are in DRBU’s Masters of Arts in Buddhist Classics program. This semester the students have been reading various spiritual biographies including the biographies of the Thai Forest masters Ajahn Mun, Ajahn Tate and Ajahn Lee Dhammadharo. The audio is from their question and answer session with Ajahn Pasanno.

TG2014.title: 2014 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat
TG2014.subtitle: “Just Right” Practice
TG2014.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

WR2015.title: Abhayagiri 2015 Winter Retreat
WR2015.subtitle: The Four Foundations of Mindfulness
WR2015.description: Ajahn Pasanno, Ajahn Karuṇadhammo, and Ajahn Ñāṇiko take turns reading suttas and teachings regarding the Four Foundations of Mindfulness. The structure often follows Right Mindfulness by Ajahn Ṭhānissaro. There are noteworth slideshows illustrating the 32 parts of the body.

UD2015-1.title: On Pilgrimage and Tudong
UD2015-1.description: The teachers describe monastic wandering pilgrimages in India, Thailand, and the United States.

UD2015-2.title: The Middle Way of Not-Self
UD2015-2.description: Ajahn Pasanno leads a discussion about the meaning and purpose of the Buddha’s teachings on not-self.

SRD2015.title: Desire or Aspiration
SRD2015.subtitle: Can a Buddhist Want Anything?
SRD2015.description: Ajahn Pasanno differentiates between skillful and unskillful desire, distinguishing between two Pāli words that are translated as desire: taṇhā, which is a cause of suffering, and chanda, which is one of the Four Bases of Success.

UD2015-3.title: Buddhist Identity in the Modern World
UD2015-3.description: After introducing the topic of Buddhist identity in the modern world, Ajahn Pasanno leads a discussion around this theme.

UD2015-4.title: Jhāna: A Practical Approach
UD2015-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno explains jhāna as a fundamental clarity and stillness that the mind can experience.

TG2015.title: 2015 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat
TG2015.subtitle: Mindfulness of Feeling
TG2015.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

UD2016-2.title: Suttas You've Never Heard Of
UD2016-2.description: Ajahn Pasanno reads and discusses a series of suttas regarding the human condition.

TG2016.title: Thanksgiving Retreat 2016
TG2016.subtitle: The Gradual Path
TG2016.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

UD2017-2.title: Two Kinds of Thought and the Removal of Distracting Thoughts
UD2017-2.description: A study and discussion of MN 19: Dvedhāvitakka Sutta and MN 20: Vitakkasaṇṭhāna Sutta.

UD2017-3.title: Practice in a Global Context
UD2017-3.subtitle: Being a Good Citizen
UD2017-3.description: Ajahn Pasanno leads an exploration of the Buddha’s teachings on living in society and how we can apply them today.

Teen2017.title: Teen Weekend 2017
Teen2017.description: This question and answer session was offered as part of the Teen Weekend on September 2, 2017 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

UD2017-4.title: Can We Function without Attachement?
UD2017-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno discusses clinging and attachment and their antidote: release and relinquishment.

WR2018-2.title: The Teaching and the Training
WR2018-2.subtitle: Eleven interviews with Ajahn Pasanno
WR2018-2.description: Towards the end of Winter Retreat 2018, Tan Suhajjo and the Abhayagiri Community ask Ajahn Pasanno questions related to monastic life.

UD2018-1.title: The New Ajahn Chah Biography
UD2018-1.description: After playing a compilation of video footage of Ajahn Chah from the BBS documentaries, Ajahn Pasanno reads from Stillness Flowing by Ajahn Jayasaro, the newly published biography of Ajahn Chah. He focuses on the chapter “Out of Compassion” which describes Ajahn Chah’s teachings to the lay community.

Path2019.title: The Path of Practice
Path2019.description: A weekend retreat lead by Ajahn Pasanno at the Victoria Insight Meditation Society in June 2019.

UD2019-4.title: Love, Attachment, and Friendship
UD2019-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno, Ajahn Karuṇadhammo, and Ajahn Ñāṇiko reflect on love, attachment, and friendship while reading from On Love by Ajahn Jayasaro.

UD2019-5.title: Developing Skill in Reflective Meditation
UD2019-5.description: Luang Por Pasanno, Ajahn Karunadhammo and Ajahn Nyaniko lead an exploration of the Buddha’s teachings on bringing a specific theme into the mind for reflection during meditation, including choosing and developing fruitful themes and the benefits of this skill.

Stanford2020.title: Stanford Community Dhamma Discussion
Stanford2020.subtitle: Reflections on the Path
Stanford2020.description: Ajahn Pasanno offers a live stream Dhamma talk and Q&A for the Buddhist Community at Stanford (BCAS).

UD2020.title: Living in a Changing Society
UD2020.subtitle: Dealing with Fear, Stress, and Worry and Cultivating Kindness, Patient Endurance, and Harmony

UD2021-1.title: Honoring the Buddha: The Mahāparinibbāna Sutta
UD2021-1.description: Under the umbrella theme of “Devotion & Ritual,” the first Upāsika Day of 2021 was on the topic of Honoring the Buddha: The Mahāparinibbāna Sutta, DN 16.

Manijeh2021.title: Tea Time Q&A with Ajahn Pasanno
Manijeh2021.description: Manijeh Motaghy facilitates a question and answer session on Zoom with Venerable Ajahn Pasanno regarding how to use the Buddha’s teachings to relieve the stress of life.

Anniversary2021.title: Abhayagiri 25th Anniversary Retreat
Anniversary2021.subtitle: Nine Days of Dhamma
Anniversary2021.description: In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, the senior monks of Abhayagiri Monastery offered a nine-day hybrid retreat to celebrate its 25th anniversary. Only two Q&A sessions and a talk by Ajahn Pasanno are currently included in the Archive.

Kathina2021.title: Abhayagiri Kaṭhina 2021
Kathina2021.description: Abhayagiri Monastery spread the 2021 Kaṭhina festival over a period of seven days to accommodate the necessities of the pandemic. Question and answers were recorded on days two and four.

Podcast2023.title: Following the Path of a Forest Monk
Podcast2023.subtitle: A Treasure Mountain podcast
Podcast2023.description: Sol Hanna interviews Ajahn Pasanno about his life as a monk for the Treasure Mountain Podcast.

Madison2023.title: Madison Insight Retreat 2023
Madison2023.description: A weekend residential retreat organized by Madison Insight held at Pine Lake Retreat Center in rural Wisconsin.

Rishikesh2023.title: Interreligious Retreat-Seminar on Dhamma and Non-duality
Rishikesh2023.description: Swami Atmananda invited Ajahn Pasanno to provide a Theravāda perspective on an interfaith weekend retreat at Ajatananda Ashram in Rishikesh, India.

Response.usageNotes: An excerpt of any category which has a response annotation will be found when searching for questions.
form: ++Response$!s!$++|| by $!teachers!$||$!colon!$$!"." if not text and teachers else " " + text!$
body: Response$!s!${attribution}$!colon!$$!"." if not text and teachers else " " + text!$

form: ++Teaching$!s!$++|| by $!teachers!$||$!colon!$$!"." if not text else " " + text!$
++Reflection$!s!$++|| by $!teachers!$||$!colon!$$!"." if not text else " " + text!$
++Dhamma talk$!s!$++|| offered by $!teachers!$||$!colon!$$!"." if not text else " " + text!$
body: Dhamma talk$!s!${attribution}$!colon!$$!"." if not text else " " + text!$

Quote.usageNotes: A quote from the teacher him/herself.

Indirect quote.usageNotes: The teacher quoting someone else. If the person quoted is a teacher, they should get the first tag.
form: ++Quote:++ $!prefix!$ “$!text!$”$!' — ' if suffix else ''!$$!suffix!$||$!'.' if suffix else ''!$ Quoted by $!teachers!$.

Reading.usageNotes: {teachers} should be the author(s) of the book. Use a Read by annotation to indicate who does the reading. If the book appears in the list of references, {teachers} will be set and " by {teachers}" inserted automatically. If not, plug both in manually along with the hyperlink if relevant.

form: ++Comment$!s!$++|| by $!teachers!$||$!colon!$$!"." if not text else " " + text!$
++Discussion$!s!$++|| led by $!teachers!$||$!colon!$$!"." if not text else " " + text!$

Summary.usageNotes: Used for session excerpts; can be blank. If the session excerpt has a list of items (e. g. readings), the items should be annotations to a summary excerpt.

Read by.usageNotes: If the reader is not a teacher, {teachers} should be empty and {text} specifies the name of the reader.
form: $!'Read by ' if text else ''!$$!text!$$!'.' if text else ''!$||$!'' if text else 'Read by ' + teachers + '.'!$
body: $!'Read by ' if text else ''!$$!text!$$!'.' if text else ''!${attribution}

form: $!'Translated by ' if text else ''!$$!text!$$!'.' if text else ''!$||$!'' if text else 'Translated by ' + teachers + '.'!$
body: $!'Translated by ' if text else ''!$$!text!$$!'.' if text else ''!${attribution}

form: $!'Asked by ' if text else ''!$$!text!$$!'.' if text else ''!$||$!'' if text else 'Asked by ' + teachers + '.'!$
body: $!'Asked by ' if text else ''!$$!text!$$!'.' if text else ''!${attribution}

Fragment.usageNotes: A fragment annotation indicates that the next annotation and its sub-annotations should be duplicated in a separate except following the main excerpt. The Fragment annotation itself is rendered as an audio player to play that excerpt.

Alternate audio.usageNotes: Specifes an audio file which is treated as if it were the session audio file for this excerpt. Text has the format: filename.mp3|url. End time specifies the duration of the file.

Edited audio.usageNotes: Specifes a replacedment audio file for this excerpt, which is otherwise treated as if it were taken from the session audio file. End time specifies the duration of the excerpt; if blank, use the duration specified by the excerpt start and end times.

Thanksgiving Retreats.description: The Abhayagiri Monastic Thanksgiving retreat was traditionally an annual ten-day residential retreat held at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa, California during the week of Thanksgiving. After the Angela Center closed due to fire damage in 2017 and the COVID pandemic began in 2020, the location, date, duration, and format of this retreat have varied significantly. More...

Abhayagiri Winter Retreats.description: During the months of January, February, and March, the resident community of Abhayagiri Monastery ceases all non-essential work to practice meditation. There are usually Dhamma readings nearly every day, some of which end with questions and answers regarding the teachings. More...

Spirit Rock Daylongs.description: Senior monks from Abhayagiri typically lead several daylong teaching events each year at Spirit Rock Meditation Center in Woodacre, California. More...

Upāsikā Days.description: Well-organized afternoon teaching sessions held at Abhayagiri Monastery attended by committed supporters. Themes are chosen in advance and touch upon formal meditation practice, devotional practice, sutta study, daily life practice, and social aspects of Dhamma practice. More...

Other retreats.description: Multi-day retreats held at venues around the world.

Q&ampA sessions.description: Question and answer sessions with groups of visitors or online participants.

Other.description: Events that don’t fit into any of the above categories.

Spirit Rock Meditation Center.address: 5000 Sir Francis Drake Blvd., PO Box 169, Woodacre, CA 94973
